item.title: Every Legend of Zelda Visual Aesthetic, Ranked From Worst To Best
item.content:encoded:
Every game in The Legend of Zelda series is defined, in part, by its aesthetics, the visual design choices coalescing every element into one cohesive vision. Even during the Hylian hero‚Äôs original 8-bit journey, strong art direction transformed simple sprites into sprawling labyrinths, mysterious woods, and terrible foes in the player‚Äôs imagination. While the core of Zelda‚Äôs story and gameplay has remained (until recently) mostly the same, the series reinvents itself artistically with nearly every entry.

This article was originally published on June 27, 2023. It‚Äôs been republished today following the 40th anniversary of Zelda‚Äòs launch in Japan.

Looking back on the 40 year history of the franchise, one thing is clear: Link has had a lot of looks.

Cel-shaded oceans, lonely ranches, and apocalyptic moon landings all paint the diverse canvas that is The Legend of Zelda, but which entries truly look the best? There‚Äôs no bad-looking Zelda game‚Äînot from Nintendo, anyway‚Äîbut today we want to rank the most aesthetically inspired, from least inspired to most. We‚Äôll be considering all the mainline Zelda entries, and please keep in mind that this isn‚Äôt a ranking of the best games in the series, but rather the best-looking.

Let‚Äôs step into the art gallery that is The Legend of Zelda and take a look around.

item.title: Elon Musk Reportedly Delayed An Update To Grok Because It Kept Getting Questions About Baldur‚Äôs Gate 3 Wrong
item.content:encoded:
Elon Musk, currently on track to become the world‚Äôs first trillionaire, is apparently obsessed with teaching Grok about video games. The xAI-powered chatbot was reportedly so bad at answering questions about Baldur‚Äôs Gate 3 last year that Musk actually delayed a major update to its model so the problem could be rectified.

That bizarre anecdote comes from a recent deep-dive investigation into xAI by Business Insider. Musk‚Äôs penchant for chaos and micromanagement was apparently so bad that when confronted with Grok‚Äôs inability to correctly parse details about Larian Studios‚Äô hit 2023 RPG based on Dungeons & Dragons, he pulled top engineers off other projects to get the chatbot sorted.

‚ÄúIn one instance last year, a model release was delayed for several days because Musk was dissatisfied with how the chatbot answered detailed questions about the video game ‚ÄòBaldur‚Äôs Gate,‚Äô according to people familiar with the matter. High-level engineers were pulled from other projects to improve the responses before launch, they said,‚Äù Business Insider writes.

Can I have just one normal week pic.twitter.com/bip2afWQLe

‚Äî Very AFK (@Cromwelp) February 21, 2026

Lest you think this episode was a one-off, Musk was also apparently obsessed with teaching Grok how to play League of Legends. Some former xAI employees reportedly compare how the company is run to a never-ending fire drill. There are multiple ‚Äúwar rooms‚Äù running at the Palo Alto headquarters to tackle urgent issues, including getting Grok to Challenger rank in Riot Games‚Äô popular MOBA.

‚ÄúAt the end of 2025, at least five war rooms were running simultaneously, according to three people,‚Äù writes Business Insider. ‚ÄúOne, they said, was dedicated to teaching Grok how to play one of Musk‚Äôs favorite video games, ‚ÄòLeague of Legends.'‚Äù

That definitely sounds like the unparalleled, no-drugs grindset of someone worth a trillion dollars. It‚Äôs worth noting that all of this was happening the year following Musk exposing himself as a massive cheater in games like Diablo 4 and Path of Exile 2. Baldur‚Äôs Gate 3‚Äòs own publishing head was busy calling out Musk‚Äôs promises of AI-generated video games for missing the point.

item.title: Winters Olympics Figure Skating Caps Things Off With Deadpool, Kung Fu Panda, And Mortal Kombat‚Äòs Sub-Zero
item.content:encoded:
Ever see those Facebook reels where Mortal Kombat 1 modders try to dupe strangers into thinking NetherRealm Studios added Shrek and Captain Jack Sparrow to their fighting game to decapitate one another? Something along those lines capped off this year‚Äôs figure skating competition at the 2026 Winter Olympics in Milan as Sub-Zero, Deadpool and Kung Fu Panda squared off on the global stage.

Kazakhstan skater Mikhail Shaidorov won the gold in men‚Äôs figure skating this year, the first from his country to land that prize. He‚Äôs also the first Olympic figure skater, ever, to best the Lin Kuei. During the Exhibition Gala, the closing, non-competitive, often silly segment, Shaidorov came out on the ice dressed like Jack Black‚Äôs famed Dreamworks cartoon martial artist. There he danced to Carl Douglas‚Äôs ‚ÄúKung Fu Fighting,‚Äù doing some friendly sparring with Deadpool and Sub-Zero before farting on them, the sound effect echoing in the arena of champions.

Awesome performance! Mortal Kombat makes a special appearance at the winter Olympics! @MortalKombat @noobde pic.twitter.com/dD4DVJNIhd

‚Äî The Freelancer (@TehFreelancer) February 22, 2026

It wasn‚Äôt the only bit of Disney on Ice goofiness this year. Earlier pairs skated to ‚ÄúCotton Eyed Joe‚Äù and ‚ÄúMacarena.‚Äù Georgia‚Äôs Luka Berulava, who was the one dressed like Sub-Zero, joined partner Anastasiia Metelkina (dressed like Kitana) for a routine to The Immortals‚Äô famed Mortal Kombat theme. The two ended with the warbled, dazed stance Mortal Kombatants do ahead of having their intestines ripped out.

Needless to say I have never been more confused about IP rights at the Olympic games. Earlier in the week, during competitive performances, chaos brewed as several figure skaters, such as American gold medalist Amber Glenn, struggled to secure licensing to the music used for their performances. This included Spain‚Äôs Tom√†s-LlorencÃß, who performed dressed like a Minion. This blurred even more and even stranger when Czech skaters Katerina Mrazkova and Daniel Mrazek skated to an AI-generated song clearly leaning on samples from AC/DC. However the legality shakes out, it‚Äôs clear that Fortnite-ification has already spread to the Olympic village.

item.title: The Legend Of Zelda‚Äôs Keeps Flirting With Dumping Fantasy For Sci-Fi
item.content:encoded:
Today marks the 40th anniversary of The Legend of Zelda. Originally released for the Famicom Disk System in 1986, Nintendo‚Äôs ambitious adventure kicked off the most beloved high-fantasy video game series of them all. Through decades, the tunic-wearing hero has slain stalfos, obliterated octoroks, and harassed cuccos. But behind all the sword and sorcery lies another campaign in waiting, an adventure Link has never braved but come very close to undertaking: some outer space shit.

In 2017, Breath of the Wild director Hidemaro Fujibayashi, art director Satoru Takizawa and technical director Takuhiro Dohta gave a keynote at GDC. It offered a rare and candid glimpse at the production behind the latest (and to some, greatest) Legend of Zelda, released only a few days prior. Getting a peak behind the curtain at how the toybox of physics and elemental effects came to be was a treat, but one of the more bizarre parts of the talk regarded an earlier pitch.

In a segment called ‚ÄúTrial and Error,‚Äù Takizawa reviews concepts for a version of the game called The Legend of Zelda: INVASION. ‚ÄúThis is where things got a bit dodgy,‚Äù Takizawa said. ‚ÄúAnd here‚Äôs an invasion from outer space.‚Äù

As chuckling swells in the crowd, bizarre slides of this would-be Zelda cycle. It features a UFO descending on to Hyrule, a storyboard for an alien autopsy, spacesuits and Ganondorf in what appears to be a Metallica t-shirt. Most offensive of all were slides of the most fuckboy Link ever developed. Dressed like a frosh week volunteer, Link dons baggy denim pants, a striped winter hat, a Triforce guitar and a motorcycle. To think we came this close to a Link with a Superbad poster in his room still gives me chills.

The Legend of Zelda is 40 today ü§Ø
*check notes on space*

The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild (2017): UFO concept, artist unknown
Art director Satoru Takizawa: "Some of our younger designers came up with very unique suggestions, like the idea that UFOs could invade from space and abduct cattle.‚Äù

‚Äî The Spaceshipper üöÄ (@thespaceshipper.com) 2026-02-21T10:15:00.535Z

Thankfully we got the incredible game we got instead, but it‚Äôs probably no coincidence that Takizawa brought up INVASION when discussing the design for Breath of the Wild‚Äôs ancient ruins and Guardians. Sheikah technology has a strong, otherworldly and out-of-place appearance to it. Mechanical octopus arms. Ominous glowing spotlights. Metallurgy so distant to the masonry everywhere else. Hell, Link‚Äôs main weapon is a damn smartphone. It always felt like some of the sci-fi elements remained deep in Hyrule‚Äôs soil, built by ancient visitors.

This Stargate-aside wasn‚Äôt The Legend of Zelda‚Äôs only near miss with a different genre. Fact is, since day one Shigeru Miyamoto considered giving The Legend of Zelda a harder sci-fi bent. In an interview with the French publication Gamekult, Miyamoto confirmed that the series‚Äô original idea revolved around time travel.

Obviously time travel is a frequent occurrence, but this initial concept is less Ocarina and more Back to the Future Part II. This plot seemingly concerns a bygone era of steel and shield rubbing up against strange future devices, and the source of the Triforce‚Äôs incredible magic being microchips and computer parts. In that same conversation, Miyamoto even muses that Breath of the Wild producer Eiji Aonuma might have added the Sheikah Slate as a kind of callback to this original idea. 1992‚Äôs A Link to the Past got so close to Link facing off against flying cars that concept art was drafted for a tubular, ‚Äò90s, cyberpunk Princess Zelda, resurfacing in 2013‚Äôs Hyrule Historia. Come to think of it, the title A Link to the Past would make a lot more sense for a game about time travel than one in which you merely hop between a good dimension and a scary dimension.

After 40 years, it feels unlikely that Nintendo will send Link, Zelda, Tingle, all our Hyrule friends spiraling into wormholes and far off nebulas now. When Hylians land on the moon, it usually means the moon came to the Hyrule. Nintendo has reigned in their style guide before. As they venture into movies, Netflix shows and theme parks I expect them to only become more conservative on what their IPs do and do not do. Still, as much as INVASION‚Äôs Link‚Ä¶ disturbs me, I am that steadfast Jackie Brown and Ed Wood are their best movies kind of hack who finds that great artists often do their greatest work beyond the comfort zone. Throughout the ages, people who work on Zelda seem to dream of one day lobbing Link into the cold void of space. Perhaps, one day, they will get their wish.
